result.execSummary:
The defendant James J.M. Albrecht was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Taking Hostages/Release w/o Bodily Harm [Modifiers: Repeater], a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.305(2).
  • Felon Possess Firearm [Modifiers: Repeater], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 941.29(2)(a).
  • Theft-Movable Property-Special Facts [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Dunn County Case 14CM162 dismissed/read-in.

supervisions.notes: If Probation or Extended Supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

11/10/2014:  Court finds defendant eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program.
Consecutive to: Count 1.

11/10/2014:  Court finds defendant eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program.
Consecutive to: Counts 1 and 7

Denying defendant's request for phone conference regaring DNA sample and surcharge. Per the Court, this request is not a function of the Court.

Dated 07/21/19 from Court to defendant regarding defendant's letter dated July 12, 2019 regarding DNA sample and surcharge. Per the Court, the Court Order follows statute. If the statute indicates a DNA surcharge shall be charged, despite having a previous sample available, the surcharge must be paid. If the statute does not require a new sample, you need not pay.
